body: For nine years JEAN-LUC LE DÃ›, below, the sommelier at Daniel, has shown his taste for wines from all over the world. This month he will leave his job, but with an au revoir, not an adieu: in the spring he plans to open JEAN-LUC'S WINES, a shop in the West Village. Others on the move: MICHELLE BERNSTEIN, formerly the chef at Azul in the Mandarin

body: There is a certain indefinable quality to the handful of prints and paintings that line the walls of Hope & Anchor, a restaurant in a quiet section of Red Hook, Brooklyn. ''As soon as they went up, I knew they worked for the room as a whole,'' Joseph Bernardo, one of the restaurant's owners, said as he contemplated the bright colors, the scantily
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK; An Exhibition You Can't Refuse

body: The story of Robert O. is the story of Red Hook. Growing up in the 1970's in what was one of the worst neighborhoods in Brooklyn, he saw murders and robberies of every variety, and he himself participated in the occasional gang attack. Yet as the neighborhood changed, so did he. After a few years in prison, Robert, a tall, affable guy with an
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK -- THE VOICE; A Time to Fight, a Time to Mellow

body: Silvana Nardone, left, the owner of Fanciulla Specialty Foods, a wholesale bakery in Red Hook, Brooklyn, has a new savory, herb-flecked cracker with a touch of sweetness from dried fruit. The crackers, called Wine Flats, come in currant-fennel, cherry-peppercorn and fig-rosemary flavors, all addictive on their own or with a spread of some kind. She
title: FOOD STUFF; Not To Be Confused With Saltines

body: A teenage girl walking her dog on the rooftop of a public housing complex in Red Hook yesterday afternoon discovered an abandoned infant boy, the police said. She called the authorities, who took the boy to Long Island College Hospital. The boy, who appeared to be one or two days old, was listed in stable condition last night, the police said.
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Newborn Abandoned On Rooftop

body: The handball courts in J.J. Byrne Park on Fourth Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, were relatively quiet on a recent afternoon, and not only because of the slight chill in the air or the gray tint in the autumn sky. There were still men (and a few women) of all ages scrambling around six of the eight courts, in fact, smacking blue rubber balls at
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE; Waiting, Not So Patiently, To Reclaim an Urban Oasis

body: Usmanu Salisu surveyed the tabletop scene: potatoes, apples, watermelons and squash. ''This is good, real good, and it's all fresh,'' Mr. Salisu said, inspecting a ripe Cortland apple. title: Bleak Landscapes, Green Produce; Poor Neighborhoods See Rise in Farmers' Markets

body: The notion of shopping for minimalist furniture while nibbling Swedish meatballs within view of the Statue of Liberty took a major step forward yesterday as a City Council panel approved a plan for what is likely to become New York City's first Ikea, along the Brooklyn waterfront in Red Hook. The approval came despite opposition from some residents
title: Panel Approves Plan by Ikea To Open Store In Red Hook

title: The Next TriBeCa? Stick a Pin in the Map

body: THE stray dogs are finding their way back to Athens; the shady characters are coming back, too. Heroin addicts, kept out of view for three weeks, nod out around midnight at Omonia Square, reminding the city of a dire social scourge. Seediness, kept at arm's length for a month, comes a bit too close for comfort now. Athens is getting back to normal.
title: Sports of The Times; New York Is Already Up to Speed for 2012

body: AGAIN to a secret city place: the easternmost, uppermost deck of Pier 17 at the South Street Seaport in Lower Manhattan, a sanctuary in the midst of tourists, where lounge chairs bolted to the floorboards all but demand that you pause for a while and consider. Across the East River, a corner piece of the Brooklyn jigsaw offers its tree-shadowed
title: NEW YORK 2004; Who Can Claim to Know A City of 8 Million?

title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Jill Adelman, Stephen Gandel

title: 69 Indicted In Drug Ring At Projects In Brooklyn

body: When Jay Schneider joined the Park Slope Food Co-op 24 years ago, he had to seek it out: ''I walked up and down the block three times trying to find it,'' he said one day recently while leading an orientation for potential new members. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE; An Organic Outpost Shudders As Its Sleek Successors Close In

body: Fifty-one times the rain has fallen, and eight times the snow. The glare of sun has made Brooklyn 91 degrees, and the dark of night 16. title: A Memorial Far Beyond Makeshift; Five Months Later, Paying Tribute to Two Lost Boys

body: By most measures, it was a spectacular Fourth of July in New York City, with balmy breezes, festive crowds and a vast display of pyrotechnics over the East River. title: Fireworks Pop, And So Do Complaints Of the Irritated

title: FAMILY FARE

title: Rheingold's Homecoming: Brewed Again in Brooklyn

body: A WHILE back, I awoke in my Carroll Gardens apartment to find it shaking. Whatever, man. It had been one very long work week, and I went back to sleep. When I finally got up, things were calm. title: URBAN STUDIES/SHAKING; The Mystery of the Trembling Apartment

title: RESTAURANTS; N'awlins-Crawling on Columbus

title: PUBLIC LIVES; If Brooklyn's Your Borough, Then He's Your Guy

title: When the Street Name Outlives the Street; Only Signs Remain to Tell the Story Of New York's Ever-Changing Grid

body: When the Queen Mary 2 glided past Brooklyn the other day, residents of Red Hook scrambled up to on their rooftops to watch it pass. The neighborhood, like the rest of the city, was buzzing, but not just over the ship. Days before, the city's Economic Development Corporation had announced plans to create a cruise-ship berth in Brooklyn for similar
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK; On the Waterfront, Wariness Over a Cruise-Ship Plan

body: TWO writers who helped define 20th-century New York died within the past 10 days. Hubert Selby Jr., who died last Monday, was best known for his stark novel ''Last Exit to Brooklyn, '' published in 1964 by Grove Press. His prose was all Red Hook, spare, direct, as subtle as a punch in the gut from a heavyweight boxer; he was a high school dropout.
title: NEW YORK WRITERS -- Selby and Hamburger: The Profane, and the Urbane; Jukes, Pimps and the Gowanus

body: TWO writers who helped define 20th-century New York died within the past 10 days. body: BY all accounts, the University Food Market at 115th Street and Broadway was hardly an epicurean paradise. The aisles were cramped and overcrowded, the Latina cashiers sassy. As for the stock, one regular described the produce as ''competent, not exciting,'' and though the organic meats were notable, the freezers occasionally short-circuited,
title: Obsessed!

body: In Dumbo, a high-concept exercise in nesting lust called Hadco, a demonstration center where customers can try out luxe appliances for purchase elsewhere, has opened near outposts of ABC Carpet and Home and West Elm. title: Suburban Retailing for the New Brooklyn

body: Hubert Selby Jr., the Brooklyn-born ex-merchant mariner who turned to drugs and to writing after cheating death and created a lasting vision of urban hell in his novel ''Last Exit to Brooklyn,'' died yesterday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 75. The cause was chronic pulmonary disease, said his son, Bill Selby, who added that his father's death
title: Hubert Selby Jr. Dies at 75; Wrote 'Last Exit to Brooklyn'

body: In 1995, when Vera Jeffery started working at Treasures Thrift Emporium on Smith Street, the thoroughfare was a threadbare strip little known beyond Cobble Hill and Boerum Hill, the two Brooklyn neighborhoods it separated. Ms. Jeffery, who lives in the nearby Gowanus Houses, recalls cracked sidewalks, unsavory characters and empty storefronts. Ms.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL/BOERUM HILL; Even an Outpost of Funkiness Can't Survive on a Funky Street

title: City in Deal to Restore Piers to Former Port-of-Call Glory

body: Fitfully over the years, the Brooklyn Museum of Art has given the nod to its geographic roots with showcases of borough artists. And people have been waiting for it to push more forcefully in that direction since the florescence of a local gallery scene in the 1990's. It is doing so now with ''Open House: Working in Brooklyn,'' a big, mixed-up
title: ART REVIEW; Brooklyn-ness, a State of Mind and Artistic Identity in the Un-Chelsea

title: FOOD STUFF; OFF THE MENU

body: The future of Red Hook, Brooklyn, a port and industrial area since the Civil War, may have been sealed last December, when the decision was made to convert a hulking six-story warehouse on Imlay Street, next to a container port, into 150 luxury condominiums with a dramatic view of the harbor and the Manhattan skyline. The move was cheered by some
title: A Zoning Board's Quiet Work Has Neighbors Making Noise

body: Brooklyn, which now has its own Zagat guide, now also has its own restaurant week. More than 90 restaurants are offering discounted three-course menus from Thursday through April 22. The $18.98 price recalls the year Brooklyn joined New York City, an event that Brooklynites celebrate or mourn. Here's a sampling of the restaurants that are
title: GOOD EATING; Feast of Brooklyn

body: A federal judge yesterday gave long prison sentences to two men he said lied in their testimony in a gang murder trial last year after having won promises of leniency for cooperating with prosecutors. The sentences by Judge John Gleeson of United States District Court in Brooklyn were life in prison for one of the men and 60 years for the other for
title: Long Prison Terms for 2 Men In Brooklyn Gang Murder

body: When a federal judge in Brooklyn overturned the gang-murder conviction of a Red Hook man in February because of perjury by government witnesses, he provided a rare glimpse of the murky world of prosecutors and their criminal informers. In exchange for information, prosecutors routinely offer leniency to killers, thieves and liars. Tomorrow, the
title: Trading in Lies, Some Informers Build Cases For Prosecutors

title: Child Protectors With Mail-Order Badges; A Private Group Claiming Police Powers Investigates Abuse Claims

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: NEW YORK; Listeners Wait For Answers From Hearing

body: It takes a tough borough to breed a tender fish, Dr. Martin P. Schreibman likes to say. And the roughly 3,000 Brooklyn-bred tilapia Dr. Schreibman grows in tanks in his aquaculture lab grow up hardy and with the requisite dose of attitude. To prove it, Dr. Schreibman, a biology professor at Brooklyn College, grabbed a handful of food pellets the
title: Chasing a Fish-Farming Dream; Brooklyn College Professor Sees a City of Tilapia Tanks

body: For some, South Brooklyn will always be South Brooklyn, although it is, in fact, in northern Brooklyn, and is also referred to, alternatively, as Carroll Gardens, Red Hook, Boerum Hill and the Columbia Waterfront District. But another name for the area has emerged, in the form of a well-appointed Web site and a series of sleek brochures: BoCoCa.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN; The Newest Entry In Neighborhood Scrabble

body: It seems that you can't please anyone in New York City. People complained for years about having to recycle their trash. Then they complained when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg canceled most recycling to save the city money. And they positively howled in confusion when he restored some recycling but cut collections to every other week. So it should
title: Sorting Refuse Would Be a Snap If Only They Could Sort the Rules

body: An article on Feb. 4 about development along the Brooklyn waterfront misstated the role of Community Board 6 in a now-defunct proposal by Carnival, the cruise ship company, to build a $100 million passenger terminal in Red Hook. It has generally supported the idea, but it did not negotiate a deal with Carnival.
title: Corrections

title: ART GUIDE

author: Thomas Boyle, a professor of English at Brooklyn College, is the author of several crime novels set in Brooklyn.
body: OUT here in Brooklyn, we hear that New Jersey's Nets are coming. This could be great news, but at the same time it brings back the bitter memory of the nasty departure of our baseball Dodgers in 1957. And just over a week ago, Gage & Tollner, our oldest restaurant and most charming culinary relic of the dear departed 19th century (sorry about that,
title: CITY LORE; Put Down That Violin. Now.

body: Sabato F. Catucci stalks the piers on the Red Hook waterfront in Brooklyn, where he has built a thriving business handling cargo containers, lumber, coffee and cacao beans. Mr. Catucci, the owner of American Stevedoring, has plans for a liquor distribution center on Pier 12, where his company would unload beer and spirits bound for Brooklyn, Queens
title: Is a Blue-Collar Future a Luxury on the Waterfront?

body: An army of sanitation workers stood solemnly outside a brownstone church in Red Hook, Brooklyn, yesterday morning to salute a colleague who was killed in a freakish accident while collecting trash. As bagpipes wailed, a coffin with the body of the worker, Eva M. Barrientos, was carried by an honor guard of police officers past more than 1,000
title: For a City Worker Who Picked Up the Trash, a Funeral Fit for a Queen

body: A city sanitation worker died in a freakish accident in Brooklyn yesterday after she was pinned on top of a garbage truck by a mechanical lever, city officials said. The worker, Eva Barrientos, 41 and a mother of three, had climbed on top of the truck to pull free a trash bag that had jammed the compactor when one of the truck's metal
title: City Sanitation Worker Killed In a Freakish Truck Accident

body: By Wednesday morning, Bruce C. Ratner had nearly sealed his $300 million offer to buy the Nets and move them to Brooklyn. But nothing was certain, not after a week in which his confidence soared and plummeted as he struggled to outnegotiate a rival. Around 10 o'clock, a fax arrived in Skillman, N.J., at the law office of Edwin Stier, a former
title: PRO BASKETBALL; Ratner's Path To Buy Nets Had Pitfalls And Promise

body: IF you say art and Brooklyn in the same sentence, you probably mean Williamsburg, which for about a decade has been the only viable alternative to Chelsea as a New York gallery scene. It's also an art neighborhood in the old, un-Chelsea way: artists live, work, kvetch and party there, even when their art commutes to Manhattan. Not that everything
title: ART REVIEW; Sampling Brooklyn, Keeper Of Eclectic Flames

body: Jerry Nachman, an old-style newshound who had an award-winning career in highly visible jobs in broadcast and newspaper journalism, most recently as editor in chief and vice president of the cable news network MSNBC, died late Monday or early yesterday at his home in Hoboken, N.J., MSNBC said yesterday. He was 57. Mr. Nachman, who said last January
title: Jerry Nachman Dies at 57; Award-Winning Journalist

body: The revival of Brooklyn has been painfully slow, an effort eked out neighborhood by neighborhood, with chic new restaurants in Fort Greene, artists' lofts in Williamsburg, new businesses in industrial Red Hook and the transformation of derelict factory buildings into million-dollar condominiums in an area with the unlikely name of Dumbo. But the
title: Yo, Dodgers? No Way! Brooklyn Is Betting on the Nets for Revival

body: IN a darkened bay at Red Hook's watery edge, the trolley guy of Brooklyn steps over the bits and pieces of his grand vision to board his magnificent vessel. Come on, he says, in that weary-whiny voice of his. ''I'll take you on the world's shortest trolley ride.'' He turns on the lights, rings the bell -- ding, ding -- and an 1897 trolley of
title: About New York; The Trolley Guy's Last Ride (All 12 Feet of It)
